title: Orders of magnitude (radiation)
text:
Recognized effects of higher acute <a href="Absorbed%20dose">radiation doses</a> are described in more detail in the article on <a href="radiation%20poisoning">radiation poisoning</a>. Although the <a href="International%20System%20of%20Units">International System of Units</a> (SI) defines the <a href="sievert">sievert</a> (Sv) as the unit of radiation dose equivalent, chronic radiation levels and standards are still often given in units of <a href="Roentgen%20equivalent%20man">millirem</a>s (mrem), where 1 mrem equals 1/1000 of a rem and 1 rem equals 0.01 Sv. Light radiation sickness begins at about 50–100 <a href="rad%20%28unit%29">rad</a> (0.5–1 <a href="gray%20%28unit%29">gray (Gy)</a>, 0.5–1 <a href="Sievert">Sv</a>, 50–100 <a href="Roentgen%20equivalent%20man">rem</a>, 50,000–100,000 mrem).
The following table includes some dosages for comparison purposes, using millisieverts (mSv) (one thousandth of a sievert). The concept of <a href="radiation%20hormesis">radiation hormesis</a> is relevant to this table – radiation hormesis is a <a href="hypothesis">hypothesis</a> stating that the effects of a given <a href="Acute%20toxicity">acute dose</a> may differ from the effects of an equal <a href="Dose%20fractionation%23Fractionation%20as%20cancer%20treatment">fractionated</a> dose. Thus 100 mSv is considered twice in the table below – once as received over a 5-year period, and once as an acute dose, received over a short period of time, with differing predicted effects. The table describes doses and their official limits, rather than effects.
